channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: What is mortgage occupancy fraud—an offense of which Trump officials are accusing a Fed governor?
item.description: Lenders typically offer better terms for primary residences, including lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Home sales climbed 2% in July while prices eased
item.description: The unexpected pickup in sales activity reflected a slight improvement in affordability as home-price growth slows.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Robust U.S. Activity Data Supports Dollar, Treasury Yields
item.description: U.S. businesses kept humming, defying calls for interest rate cuts and supporting the dollar.

item.title: European Business Takes Trump Tariffs in Stride
item.description: European business activity continues to prove resilient into the second half of the year, surveys showed, despite the American trade tariffs that have weighed on some companies.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Business Activity Gains Pace as Manufacturing Rebounds
item.description: U.S. business activity expanded at its fastest pace this year as the factory sector rebounded strongly, though trade tariffs were fueling inflation in input prices, according to the S&P Global Flash U.S. Composite PMI.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The U.S. will keep the current 27.5% tariffs on automobiles from the EU until the 27-nation bloc moves to reduce levies on a variety of American goods
item.description: The auto tariffs will decrease to 15% when the European Union introduces legislation to reduce rates on U.S. goods.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Rose Last Week
item.description: In the week through Aug. 16, new jobless-claims filings rose to 235,000, up from 224,000 a week earlier. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal were forecasting 225,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Stalling New Zealand Economy a Test Case for Trade Chaos
item.description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand’s chief economist said the trade-reliant economy will continue to face stiff headwinds.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: President Trump and his allies are waging a caustic, unprecedented campaign to pressure Fed Chair Jerome Powell into cutting interest rates. Powell is trying to keep his cool in the hot seat.
item.description: The president and his allies accuse Powell of dragging his feet on interest-rate cuts, in a caustic and unprecedented pressure campaign.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Fed minutes from the July meeting reveal broad support among governors for holding rates steady even though two backed a rate cut
item.description: “Almost all” officials backed July’s interest-rate decision, even though two governors backed a rate cut, according to a meeting summary.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: President Trump has called on a Biden-appointed Federal Reserve governor to resign after one of his administration officials accused her of mortgage fraud
item.description: President calls on Fed governor Lisa Cook to resign after fraud claim. She says, “I have no intention of being bullied.”
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: Europe Should Deepen Ties With Non-U.S. Trade Partners, Lagarde Says
item.description: “Recent trade deals have alleviated, but certainly not eliminated, global uncertainty, which persists on account of the unpredictable policy environment,” Lagarde told a panel on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Indonesia’s Central Bank Delivers Back-To-Back Rate Cut to Support Growth
item.description: The decision is consistent with the central bank’s inflation forecasts for 2025 and 2026 to remain within the 1.5%-3.5% target range, rupiah stability and the need to support economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: Hastily drafted trade accords between the U.S. and allies in Europe and Asia leave questions about who promised what
item.description: The hastily drafted trade accords leave questions about who promised what.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Japan’s Exports Fall for Third Consecutive Month
item.description: Japan’s exports fell for a third consecutive month in July amid fears over the impact of higher U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Kosaku Narioka

item.title: Housing construction in the U.S. jumped much more than expected in July, reflecting a recovery in the multifamily market as developers respond to demand for rental housing
item.description: Apartment construction is climbing steadily, while the construction of single-family homes is declining.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: European Trade Takes Fresh Tariff Hit as U.S. Exports Slump
item.description: The EU’s exports to the U.S. declined in June and hit their lowest level since the end of 2023, according to statistics agency Eurostat.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Global Economy Took Tariff Hike in Its Stride, But Stronger Headwinds Are Ahead
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Global economic growth has held up better than expected when the threat of high tariffs loomed.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Mortgage rates edged down to their lowest level of the year, offering a dash of hope to prospective buyers who have been forced to the sidelines
item.description: Elevated rates and home prices have kept homeownership out of reach for many prospective home buyers.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of people seeking unemployment benefits fell to 224,000 in the week through Aug. 9, down from 227,000 a week earlier. Analysts polled had expected 229,000 new claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Immediately preceding and following the pandemic, wages for poor workers began rising much faster than they did for the rich. That era may have come to at least a temporary halt.
item.description: Wage growth for top earners once again outstripped gains for those at the bottom.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: U.S. Employment Trends Weaken, Underlining Labor-Market Jitters
item.description: The Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index fell to 107.55 in July from an upwardly revised 108.19 in June, the research group said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Anxious shoppers, concerned about inflation and their personal finances, are cutting their spending to focus on essentials
item.description: Generic brands and bulk buying are on the rise as shoppers find themselves in a summer of economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: A chief White House economic adviser said that Trump wants allies placed in the Bureau of Labor Statistics after the agency published a dismal jobs report and the president fired its commissioner
item.description: Kevin Hassett said the president wants his own people at the agency to provide “more transparent and reliable” jobs data.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: Four charts show how the condo market is floundering
item.description: More condos are on the market, and units are taking longer to sell.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Pending Home Sales Fell Unexpectedly in June
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. unexpectedly declined in June, as high prices and mortgage rates persist.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Consumer-Confidence Survey Improved in July
item.description: The Conference Board’s consumer-confidence index climbed to 97.2, from 95.2 in June. But American consumers’ economic mood remained clouded by tariff and labor market concerns.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Canada Housing Market Braces for Extended Pricing Slump
item.description: Home buyers and builders in Canada are in retreat, adding to the woes of an economy struggling under the weight of President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Contracts as U.S. Front-Running Cools
item.description: A surge in exports to the U.S. which led Ireland to far outstrip the growth rates of other rich economies waned in the three months through June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Capital Account: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans
item.description: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: Friday marked the second-straight time the Bank of Russia cut its interest rate after it lowered borrowing costs in early June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Retailers Get Summer Boost as Drinks Sales Soar
item.description: Retail sales were 0.9% higher on month in June, with alcoholic and nonalcoholic drinks among the products which saw higher sales.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Are Feeling Gloomier Amid Foundering Economy, Rising Prices
item.description: U.K. consumer sentiment worsened as the country faces an unhappy combination of weak growth and still-high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Global Economies Show Resilience Despite Tariff Fears, Surveys Show
item.description: The U.S. economy and its peers in Europe and Asia continued to show resilience in the face of high levels of uncertainty about the future of trade and international relations, although export orders weakened.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: German Consumer Confidence Hit by Economic Uncertainty
item.description: Sentiment continued to worsen as growing economic uncertainty encouraged shoppers to save rather than spend, according to a monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Leading Economies Must Work Together to Fix Imbalances, or Face Instability, Says BOE’s Bailey
item.description: The U.S., China and other leading economies should work together to agree on a set of national policies that will help narrow the large imbalances that now threaten the global trade system, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
